feed.title: Combined summary - BitMail.sf.net - encrypted p2p email

entry.title: Combined summary - BitMail.sf.net - encrypted p2p email
entry.summary: In August 2013, Randolph D. asked if anyone had tested a secure encrypted peer-to-peer email service found at http://bitmail.sf.net. The Doctor, developer of Project Byzantium, responded that they hadn't tested it recently as it is CPU and network intensive, which could be harmful to the user's needs. They recommended reading the security analyses of Bitmessage but haven't had the time to do so themselves. The security analyses can be found at https://bitmessage.org/forum/index.php?topic=1666.0 and http://www.reddit.com/r/bitmessage/comments/1fwyx7/a_security_analysis_of_bitmessage/. In an email thread on the Bitcoin-development mailing list, a member corrected another member who had mixed up BitMail with BitMessage. The correction included a link to BitMail's website, which offers secure encrypted peer-to-peer email services. The email signature of the message included links to Project Byzantium, a developer project, and the personal website of The Doctor, who sent the email. Additionally, the email contained an advertisement for AppDynamics Lite, a troubleshooting tool for Java and .NET code.On August 13th, 2013, The Doctor made an error in a message where he mixed up BitMail with BitMessage. BitMail is a different software from BitMessage and can be found at http://bitmail.sf.net. The Doctor's PGP key is 0x807B17C1 / 7960 1CDC 85C9 0B63 8D9F DD89 3BD8 FF2B 807B 17C1, and his website is https://drwho.virtadpt.net/. The Doctor's message has a GPG signature using version 2.0.20 of GnuPG for verification.Wendell posted a brief message pleading with Jesus to stop something on grabhive.com and linked it to a Twitter account and a GPG key. In an email sent on August 9th, 2013 at 9:01 PM, Randolph D. asked if anyone had tested a secure encrypted peer-to-peer email service, providing links to the service's source code repository and commit browser.Bitmail is a secure encrypted peer-to-peer email service that has been tested by users. The service can be accessed through http://bitmail.sf.net and the SVN link for Spot-On-Code can be found at svn checkout svn://svn.code.sf.net/p/spot-on/code/ spot-on-code. The commit browser for Spot-On-Code can be viewed at http://sourceforge.net/p/spot-on/code/commit_browser.
